chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
After this, I saw another angel coming down from heaven with great power, and the earth was illuminated by his brightness. This symbolizes the destruction of worldly wisdom, much like the fall of Jericho. When describing the downfall of an earthly kingdom, he mentions that this angel has great power, indicating that a stronger force has come to battle a strong one. This suggests that the true light of wisdom has arrived, overshadowing worldly wisdom, and showing the wise of the world and earthly kings who rely on their strength that it is invincible in both power and knowledge.

He says, "The earth was lit up by his brightness." And he cried out with a loud and strong voice, saying, "Babylon the great has fallen, and has become a dwelling place for demons, and a refuge for every unclean spirit, and for every unclean and hateful bird."

I believe this signifies the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, whom Isaiah refers to as the angel of great counsel. In his first coming, as mentioned in Matthew, "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is near," he was dismantling the efforts of secular power. The earth was illuminated by his brightness because he is the true light that enlightens every person who comes into this world.

However, the next part might trouble some readers, as it says, "It has become a dwelling place for demons, etc." If Babylon has fallen, how has it become a dwelling place and refuge for demons, unclean spirits, and birds? Perhaps it is because, by falling into many transgressions, it has made itself suitable for the habitation of demons, with its healthy part destroyed by its dissolute lifestyle.

What once rose in the sea of this world against the faith of Christ with strong waves of persecution now groans, restrained within narrower bounds, and rages enclosed like a bottled-up storm. As we sing in the Psalm, "He gathers the waters of the sea like in a bottle, he places the deeps in storehouses."

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
What was once feared by Christians now fears Christians, as they witness the decrees of princes granting privileges to the religious and even to soldiers.

However, part of it has become a dwelling place and refuge for demons, where it is destroyed all around and rebuilt for the better. It is shattered and toppled in its pride, rightfully said to have fallen to ruin.

It is signified by spiritual wickedness in the form of birds, as confirmed in the Book of Genesis, where it is said that Abraham drove away the birds descending upon the divided carcasses. (Genesis 15)

Because all nations have drunk from the wine of her wrath and fornication, and the kings of the earth have committed fornication with her, and the merchants of the earth have been enriched by her excessive luxuries.

Here he names three kinds of vices and introduces the same number of persons who transgress: greed, which according to the Apostle is called idolatry; (Ephesians 5) lust, in the name of fornication; (Colossians 3) and gluttony, which the Lord warns against, saying: Do not let your hearts be weighed down with carousing and drunkenness. (Luke 21)

He says the kings of the earth have committed fornication with her. Greed is implied when he says the merchants have been enriched, although some prefer to interpret this as wealth gained through sins rather than resources, designating nations as the mixed multitude of common people. Kings are those who seem to excel temporarily among them, and merchants are those who, longing for earthly gains, exchange their souls for temporal abundance in an unfortunate trade, acting contrary to the teachings of the Lord, who says: What can a man give in exchange for his soul? (Matthew 16)

I heard another voice from heaven saying. The hearing of the heavenly voice is for those whom He foreknew and predestined to be conformed to the image of His Son; (Romans 8) and, The Lord knows those who are His; (Second Timothy 2) and similar things.

Finally, it follows: Come out of her, my people, so that you do not partake in her sins.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
So far, it seems to me this pertains to the first coming, where, until the end of the age, the good tolerate the evil mixed among them. This way, they neither consider abandoning the good nor following the evil through harmful imitation. Thus, the prophetic words are fulfilled in Isaiah fifty-two: "Depart from their midst, and do not touch anything unclean," since the righteous should not mix with the wicked, not by physical departure but by departing from the most wicked will.

It continues: "And do not be struck by their plagues, for their sins have reached up to heaven, and the Lord God remembers their iniquities, and therefore repays them double. And in the people with whom they mixed, double is mixed back to them: and as much as they glorified themselves and lived in luxury, so much torment and grief is given to them, because she says in her heart, 'I am a queen, I am not a widow, and I will never see mourning.' Therefore, her plagues will come in one hour, death, mourning, and famine, and she will be burned with fire, for the Lord who judges her is mighty."

All these things are believed to pertain to the second coming when, at the examination of the final judgment, the company of the wicked will be excluded and justly punished, so that those who sinned temporarily will be punished eternally. This is what is meant by: "Repay her double, and double has been mixed back to her," so that those who enjoyed fleeting pleasures will be tormented with eternal suffering.

And Christ is foretold in the Psalm to free his own from usury. Psalm seventy-one says: "He will redeem their souls from usury and iniquities." Those, however, are said to be burned with perpetual fire, afflicted by famine: then indeed, when those who now hunger and thirst for righteousness, as stated in Matthew chapter five, will receive incorruptible satisfaction.

Truly, they die because God abandons them. For just as the body dies when the soul departs, so the soul is believed to die when God abandons it. Moreover, the mourning for them is what Christ says in the Gospel of Luke.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Woe to those who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep. God, wanting to show His people unharmed from these plagues, says: Do not be struck by His plagues. It is as if He were saying: Since you did not want to change your ways and be like sinners, you will not receive the same punishment. We cannot avoid these plagues by our own strength; it is granted to us only by the grace of God.

But the Holy Spirit, keeping the proper order, wanted to declare that those who are pious in heart are not captivated and are in no way tormented by the approval of the wicked. For the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God, and torment will not touch them. Wisdom 3.

In this way, He outlines future events, showing that the punishments to come should not be considered as of this world, as they will soon conclude the final course, as proven by the following. For the Lord, predicting the destruction of the world, added: Luke 21: But the end is not immediate.

And the kings of the earth who committed adultery with her and lived in luxury will weep and mourn over her when they see the smoke of her burning. Standing far off because of the fear of her torment, they will say: Woe, woe, the great city, Babylon, the mighty city, for in one hour your judgment has come. And the merchants of the earth will weep and mourn over her, because no one buys their merchandise anymore.

How is it certain that the same Babylon is referred to by different names, whether from the kings of the earth, from the nations, or from the merchants, if they are said to stand far off from her burning, lamenting her not with shared suffering but with a pitiable consideration? Unless, as I have said, we should not take this as the absolute end of the world here, but as a reduction of human affairs and the destruction of various nations.

For he says that the pomp of worldly riches will be taken away, through which, to fulfill wicked desires, the opportunities of carnal pleasures surrounded, somehow offering the occasion for importunity.

When this is removed due to deficiency and desolation imposed by divine judgments, certain survivors are reported to mourn the destruction of others. Therefore, they are said to stand at a distance and fear similar punishment. Perhaps this pertains to the fact that they are said to see the smoke of the fire as a sign of eternal fire. Smoke indeed gives an indication of future flames.

It then describes if there are any things necessary for human use, if there are any things known to be useful for worldly purposes, greatly desired by the greedy and carnal, but also those things that are delightfully known to be enjoyed by the well-known five senses of the flesh, and it pronounces them to be gone, in this way: The merchandise of gold and silver and precious stones and pearls and silk.

Up to this point, it is about the utility of places. Thus, purple and scarlet cloth, and every kind of cedar wood and every vessel of ivory made from precious wood, and bronze, and iron, and marble. Up to this point, it also mentions things related to the sense of sight.

The same applies to what pertains to the sense of smell, following: And cinnamon, and incense, and ointment. From ointment, it also includes touch: and frankincense, he says.

Therefore, he added things reduced to taste and use, saying: and wine, and oil, and wheat. Furthermore, he places beasts and cattle, and horses, and carriages, and slaves, and animals of various kinds for the sake of utility. He also says: The desire of your fruits of your soul has departed from you. This also refers to sight and taste.

And all those rich and splendid things have perished from you, and you will no longer find them. Your merchants who became wealthy from it will stand at a distance because of the fear of its punishment, weeping and mourning, and saying, Alas, alas, that great city, clothed in purple and fine linen and scarlet, and adorned with gold and precious stones and pearls, in one hour such great wealth has been destroyed. The hour here is proven to be placed for a time by the judgments of many testimonies, and every shipmaster, and everyone who sails anywhere, and sailors and all who live by the sea, will stand at a distance: seeing the smoke of its burning, saying: What city is like this great city?

<speak>
  They will throw dust on their heads, symbolizing their blame on their leaders who deceived them and led to their downfall. They will cry, weeping and mourning loudly: "Woe, woe to that great city, where all who had ships on the sea became rich from her wealth, because in one hour she has been destroyed."

  <break time="1s"/>

  Since many are often moved to repentance by such destruction, if we consider those places as a warning related to the people, it makes sense that they will stand at a distance and cry out, seeing the smoke of her burning.

  This implies that it's better to avoid falling with the lost and instead achieve stability through sudden conversion. Their Lord makes them stand or fall, which should be understood not as physical standing, but as a firm conversion of the mind in faith.

  <break time="1s"/>

  So, when they mourn for others who are perishing, they are understood to be doing fruitful penance. Hence, the Apostle says in Ephesians chapter 2: "When you were dead in your trespasses and sins, in which you once walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, the spirit that is now at work in the sons of disobedience, among whom we all once lived in the desires of our flesh, doing the will of the flesh and the mind, and were by nature children of wrath, like the rest of mankind."

  According to these words of the Apostle, this place can be applied to the persons of the converted. For no one can be found good who was not first bad. Hence, the Psalm 118: "I have regarded all the sinners of the earth as transgressors"; perhaps this follows: "Rejoice over her, O heavens and saints and apostles and prophets, for God has judged your judgment on her."

  <break time="1s"/>

  And a mighty angel took up a stone like a great millstone and threw it into the sea, saying: "So will Babylon the great city be thrown down with violence and will be found no more."

  We know that the Lord said in the Gospel of Matthew...</speak>

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
"Woe to the world because of offenses, and to those who cause them: Woe to the person through whom the offense comes; it would be better for them if a millstone were put around their neck and they were thrown into the sea, than to cause one of these little ones to stumble. This means that the authors of offenses should be punished with such a penalty. This is not only to be taken in the context of litigious offenses but of every kind of sin, according to the rule which the Holy Scripture states, either by the Lord saying (Matthew 18:9): 'If your eye, foot, or hand causes you to stumble,' or by Paul the apostle in First Corinthians (First Corinthians 11:29): 'Who is offended, and I do not burn?'

To this sense, the Psalm (Psalm 121:6) concurs, saying: 'The sun shall not harm you by day, nor the moon by night,' where even false beliefs about Christ and the Church, that is, about the sun and the moon, are admitted, or about the sins of adversity and prosperity, which refer to the moon or the sun, all seem to be included under the general term of offenses. This also implies that the author of the offense, that is, any sin, should be drowned like a millstone. The millstone here seems to represent the weight of sins, which are contracted from temporal matters.

For the Lord teaches that the millstone is placed in the circle of worldly affairs when he says: 'Two women will be grinding at the mill, and the sound of harpists, musicians, flutists, and trumpeters will no longer be heard in you.' He had deferred the sound of those five senses, which he now fully expresses, and also predicted that they would be taken away, as if to say: 'Whatever is beautiful to the sight, sweet to the ear, pleasant to the touch, delightful to the smell, and enjoyable to the taste, will pass away from the world.'

And not satisfied with this, he added also about those things which pertain to the use of human life, saying: 'No craftsman of any craft will be found in you anymore, and the sound of the mill will no longer be heard in you, nor will the light of a lamp shine in you, and the voice of the bridegroom and bride will no longer be heard in you.' And he says the reason why: 'because your merchants were the great men of the earth, because by your sorceries all the nations were deceived.'"

rerum circuitu poni Dominus docet, cum
dicit: Duae molentes in mola. Et vox citharaedorum,
et musicorum, et symphoniacorum, et tubicinum, jam
non audietur in te. De illis quinque sensibus sonum
distulerat, quem nunc satianter expressit, quem etiam
 inter alia de modo auferri praedixit, ac si diceret:
Quidquid visu pulchrum, auditu canorum, tactu blandum,
odoratu suave, gustu delectabile, de saeculo
transiturum est. Et ne his contentos esse sivisset,
adjecit etiam de his quae ad usum humanae vitae pertinent,
dicens: Neque ullus artifex ullius artis invenietur
in te amplius, et vox molae non audietur in te, 
jam neque lumen lucernae lucebit tibi, et vox sponsi et
sponsae non audietur in te amplius. Et dicit quo merito:
quia negotiantes tui fuerunt magistratus terrae,
quia maleficiis in tuis exerraverunt omnes gentes.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: It's like saying: Because you misused temporal goods in your life, you will justly be deprived of them further and condemned to eternal punishments. In you, the blood of the prophets and saints was found, along with all those killed on earth. This makes it clear that the entire body of the devil is rebuked for its excesses in one city, Babylon. We don't know if prophets and martyrs were killed in the same city, but there is one city in the society of the impious. It follows.
chunks.original_latin:
Ac si diceret: Quia in vita tua male usa es temporalibus
bonis, et ipsis juste ultra fraudaberis, et poenis
aeternis damnanda restringeris. Et in te sanguis
prophetarum et sanctorum inventus est, et omnium occisorum
 super terram. Hic apertius declaratur, totum
in una civitate Babyloniae corpus diaboli de suis excessibus
increpari. Neque enim in qua civitate prophetas,
in eadem novimus occisos martyres, quantum
attinet ad loci significationem, cum tamen una
sit civitas impiorum societate. Sequitur.
